messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Vladimir Ritz Bossicard [mailto:vladimir@...]
>
> > you are talking about. I don't see any benefits of using
> > junit-addons for that particular task, it is all there,
> > in junit.jar.
>
> To see the benefits, simply try with junit.jar to:
>
> 1) write a custom listener (e.g. that outputs the name of the test
> currently executed)
> 2) register this listener
> 3) execute the tests

Having done this, it's not hard once you figure it out. The key is to admit that you can't register a custom listener with the framework as it is (partly because of a bug in BaseTestRunner and partly because BaseTestRunner is not well designed for extension). Instead, you must write your own TestRunner and register your listener with that.

With a little copy and paste coding, writing your own TestRunner is pretty easy.

But, that said, JUnit should be refactored to make the whole test runner subsystem more extensible. I think it can be done with a little work -- probably about the same amount of work it takes to use junit-addons to roll your own.

Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA
